name: Forcyte Biotechnologies
headline: Discover drugs that control how much cells "squeeze" to treat disease
description:
In a nutshell: many diseases are caused by how much your cells squeeze (asthma, fibrosis, others). We discover drugs that control how much cells squeeze, with ease, to treat disease.

We use patented bioMEMS technology to turn cell strength (cells' ability to pull/ squeeze) into a quantifiable metric in drug discovery, to help find better drugs for mechanical diseases. 

We screen 100,000s of drugs against numerous contractile human cell types to comprehensively map human mechanobiology (the "contractome") and identify promising drug development starting points to deliver novel medicines to treat mechanically-driven diseases including asthma, hypertension, preterm labor, fibrosis, and others.

founders.name: Ivan Pushkarsky, Founder
founders.description: CEO and Co-founder of Forcyte which is based on my PhD work at UCLA with co-founder and PhD Advisor, Prof. Dino Di Carlo. Worked on tech since 2013, lead-authored multiple publications including Nature BME, and lead commercialization by winning SBIR grants, securing tech transfer and building early team.

founders.name: Dino Di Carlo, Founder
founders.description: Dino Di Carlo is a Professor, inventor, and entrepreneur with >50 issued patents. He is the Armond and Elena Hairapetian endowed chair in Engineering and Medicine at UCLA. His academic research has focused at the interface of micro & nanosystems, data science, and the ultimate limits of biology (single cells and molecules). Over the last 10 years, Dr. Di Carlo co-founded seven startup companies in life science research tools, diagnostics, medical device, and pharmaceutical industries.

## Charting Human Mechanobiology
Forcyte is building the world’s most comprehensive dataset in mechanobiology –mapping **genomics** and **pharmacology** to **mechanical cell function** for the first time to enable more effective therapies. 
[ Learn more about Mechanomics  ](https://forcytebio.com/<https:/forcytebio.com/vision/>)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/t2.png)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/v1.png)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/v3.png)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/gears-e1689834374681.png)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/v4.png)
![](https://forcytebio.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/compasswhite.png)
## **Cell contractility:** a fundamental property in _all cells_
## Finding better drugs faster by focusing on what matters: **function**
We recognize that the human body operates not only through electrical and chemical processes but also through **mechanical systems**. Disruptions in normal mechanical function at the cellular and tissue level can lead to numerous diseases – some of the biggest in the world! – and we believe the solution lies in understanding cell function.
[ Explore Forcyte's FLECS Plaform ](https://forcytebio.com/<https:/forcytebio.com/flecs-platform/>)
###### Partner with us 
## Let's unlock mechanomics to advance your pipeline
Learn more about how our platform enables****better biology** , **better chemistry** & **better translation****

generated_description:
Forcyte Biotechnologies is a dynamic player in the biotech field, focusing on understanding and manipulating how cells "squeeze." Founded in 2017 and based in Los Angeles, CA, the company emerged from Y Combinator's Winter 2021 batch and operates with a tight-knit team of five dedicated employees.

The crux of Forcyte's mission is this: diseases like asthma, fibrosis, and hypertension stem from mechanical dysfunction in cells. Their innovative approach involves a proprietary technology called bioMEMS, which quantifies cellular contractility—the cells' ability to pull and squeeze—creating a tangible metric in drug discovery. This focus allows them to screen hundreds of thousands of potential drugs against various contractile human cell types, thus mapping the "contractome"—the detailed landscape of human mechanobiology.

At its core, Forcyte is building a comprehensive dataset that links genomics and pharmacology to mechanical cell function. This alignment offers a fresh perspective that could lead to novel therapies for mechanically-driven diseases, not just in academia but also as viable commercial solutions. Their FLECS platform facilitates a functional-first approach to biology, which means they care deeply about understanding the actual mechanics at play in cellular behaviors rather than merely relying on chemical interactions.

In essence, Forcyte is all about harnessing the power of mechanomics to advocate for better biology, chemistry, and clinical translation in drug development. They are not just another biotech company; they are pioneering a whole new way of looking at disease and treatment through the lens of cell mechanics. You can explore more about their unique vision and ongoing research on their website [Forcyte Biotechnologies](https://forcytebio.com/).
